div.p: A CATECHISME in briefe Queſtions and Anſweres, CONTAINING SVCH Things as are to be knowne or had by all ſuch as would partake the Sacrament of the Lords Supper with comfort
OXFORD, Printed by I. L. An. Dom. 1629.

p.hi: DOE you purpoſe to come to the Sacrament?

div.p: A. Yes, 1 Cor. 11.14. for why ſhould I diſobey Chriſt, and depriue my ſoule of benefit.
Q. Doe all receiue benefit which come to the Sacrament?
A. No: ſome are better, 1 Cor. 11.27. & 17. ſome are worſe.
Q. Who are better?
A. Such as come with due preparation.
Q. Who come preparedly? 2 Chron. 3 • .3.18.19. 1 Cor: 11.28.

A. Such only as by examination finde in themſelues ſome competent meaſure of knowledg, appetite, repentance, faith, loue and reſolution to keepe the couenant which in this ſacrament they renew with Chriſt.
Q. Why is knowledg neceſſary to worthy communicating?

A. Becauſe examination is neceſſary which cannot be without knowledg, 1. Cor. 11.28 & 29. nor without it can we diſcerne the Lords body
and ſo ſhall prophane this Sacrament.
Q. What muſt a man know?
A. He ſhould know the grounds of Chriſtian religion in generall, but eſpecially himſelfe, God and the nature of this Sacrament.
Q. Why muſt a man know the grounds of Chriſtian religion in generall.

A. Becauſe no man ſhould be ignorant of the myſteries of his calling, 2 Pet. 3.18. Hoſ. 4.6. much leſſe a Chriſtian, nor can a man know any one principle as he ſhould doe without ſome generall knowledg of all.
Q. What muſt he know concerning himſelfe?
A. What perfection he had by creation, what miſery by corruption, what benefit by renovation.
Q. What was our perfection by creation?
A. We were created after Gods image which conſiſts in knowledg and holineſſe. Gen. 1.26.27. Eph. 4.24. Coll 3.10. Rom. 4.12. Eph. 2.1.2.3.
Q. What is our miſery by corruption?
A. We are guilty of Adams ſinne deprived of the image of God, prone to all ſin, ſlaues of Sathan children of wrath, that is, lyable to Gods iudgments here, death and hell hereafter.
Q. What benefit haue we by renouation.

A. The guilt of our ſinnes is purged by the blood of Chriſt we haue in part the image of God renewed vpon vs in knowledg and holineſſe, 1 Cor. 6.11. Coll. 3.10. Rom. 8.15.16.17. and haue our right to heauen, reſtored.
Q. Why is this knowledg of himſelfe neceſſary.

A. Becauſe till he know his miſery in himſelfe and the helpe he may haue by Chriſt, Mat. 11.28. Mat. 9.12. he will neither care for Chriſt nor this ſacrament nor any other meanes that conuaies Chriſt.
Q. What muſt he know concerning God.
A. The excellency and glory of the deity in his eſſence and attributes, Exod. 34.6.7. 1 Ioh. 5.17. the myſterie of the perſons three in one eſſence & one eſſence whole in three perſons.
Q. Why muſt a man haue this knowledg of God?

A. Vnleſſe he know him in his eſſence he will not care for this or any part of his worſhip vnleſſe he know the Trinitie in Vnitie he cannot know Chriſt who is the author and matter of this Sacrament. Heb. 11.6. Ioh. 1.14.
Q. What is a Sacrament?
A. An ordinance of God wherein by outward ſignes our faith is confirmed in the couenant of God. Gen. 17.10.11. Exod. 12.13
Q. What is the couenant of God?
A. A compact betweene God and man wherein God requires ſome ſeruice and promiſeth ſome reward, Gen. 17.1. 2. Exod. 19.5.6.7.8. man promiſeth obedience and expecteth ſome reward.
Q. How many covenants hath God made with his church?
A. Two: Gen. 3.15. the firſt of workes giuen to Adam in Paradice, the other of grace made with Adam after his fall and continued to vs though diverſly in reſpect of the externall manifeſtation.
Q. What is the covenant of grace?

A. A compact betweene God and the elect wherein God freely promiſeth to them pardon of ſinne and power againſt it and ſaluation in Chriſt, Act. 5.31. Ioh. 3.16. Act. 2 38. & 16.31. 1 Pet. 1.14.15. and requires from them repentance faith and new obedience.
Q. What is the difference betweene the couenant of grace and the other of workes?

A. They differ two waies the one requires perfect obedience as the condition, Eze. 36.25.26 27. Acts 5.31. the other only repentance faith and ſyncere obedience, the one requires the condition to be done by our owne ſtrength, but in the couevant of Grace though God require a condition he workes it in vs.

Q. How many ſacraments are there annexed
to the Goſpell?
A. Two: baptiſme and the Lords ſupper.
Q. How doth it appeare there bee but two Sacraments?
A. Chriſt hath ordained no more giuen commiſſion to his Miniſters to adminiſter no more, Mat. 26.28.19. wee need no more then to haue entrance and growth in. Chriſt ſignified.
Q. What is the Lords ſupper?

A. It is a Sacrament of the renewed couenant ordained of Chriſt, 1 Cor. 1 23.24.25 26. wherein by the vſe of bread and wine rightly adminiſtred and receiued Chriſt Ieſus and all his benefits is ſignified, ſealed and exhibited vnto vs.
Q. Who is the author of this Sacrament?
A. Chriſt Ieſus, who inſtituted it at his laſt ſupper. Mat. 26.2
Q. Who is Chriſt.
A. In perſon God and man, in office our Saviour and redeemer. 1 Tim. 3.16. Coll: Phil. 2.5.7. 1.14. Mat. 1.21.
Q. Why did Chrict ordaine this Sacrament?

A. Firſt to continue the memory of his death. 1. Cor. 11.24 26. Mat. 6.35. Secondly to Manifeſt and exhibit the fulneſſe of refreſhing that is in Chriſt. 3 To comfort vs after temptation by renewing our couenant, to ſtrengthen our faith, 1 Cor. 10.17. to ſignifie and increaſe mutuall loue and vnitie.
Q. What is the matter of this Sacrament?

A. Twofold: inward, which is Chriſt and his benefits,
• at. 26.26. • .28. outward to wit the ſignes.
Q. What be the ſignes?
A. Twofold: elementall and rituall the one ſignifying Chriſt the other the application of him.
Q. What be the elementall ſignes?

A. Bread and wine, the one ſignifying the body,
• ſat. 26.16. •• .28. the other the blood of Chriſt.
Q. What be the rituall ſignes?

A. Rites or actions, Cor. 11. • . • at. 26.28. as the breaking of the bread ſignifying the ſufferings of Chriſt, the powring out of the wine that his blood was ſhed, the miniſter giuing the element ſignifies God the Father giuing Chriſt, the peoples taking, the elements ſignifying their receiuing Chriſt by faith.
Q. What vnion is there betweene the ſignes and the thing ſignified?

A. Not viſible or locall, but myſticall and ſpirituall,
• om. 8.34. • ct. 3.21. yet true and reall.
Q. How doe wee partake of them?

A. The ſignes wee partake corporally, the thing ſignified ſpiritually according to their proper natures.
• ſat. 26.26. • 7.
Q. How can we partake of Chriſt and hee in heauen?
A. By hauing a right and title giuen to vs, as wee receiue land by evidences, not as we take a medicine in a box.
Q. What difference is there betweene Sacramentall and common bread?
A. None in nature, only in vſe, 1 Cor. 11.26. this being ſet apart for holy vſe.
Q. How haue theſe elements this holy relation to ſeale and repreſent ſpirituall things?

A, 1 Cor. 11.23.24.25. By being conſecrated to this holy vſe which conſecration conſiſts partly in Chriſts firſt inſtitution of ſuch elements for ſuch vſe partly in the Miniſters declaring Chriſts inſtitution, bleſſing God for our rdemption and theſe ſeals of it, praying to him for to bleſſe the elements for the preſent to that holy vſe, to which himſelfe hath ordained them.
Q. What is the ſecond thing neceſſary in a worthy communicant?
A. Appetite. Iſa. 55.1.
Q. Why is appetite neceſſary?
A, Becauſe this ſacrament is a ſpirituall feaſt, Ioh. 7.37. Rev. 22.15. and our invitation and welcome depends vpon it.
Q. Why muſt we deſire it?
A. Not for cuſtome or company but in obedience to God, and for the benefit of our ſouks.
Q. How ſhall a man know he hath a deſire?
A. Deſire is the inclination of our hearts after a thing which is of it ſelfe diſcerneable to vs.
Q. How ſhall wee know the ſyncerity of our deſires?
A. By the grounds which in our conſciences we finde doe moue vs to it & by our conſtancy of communicating at all opportunities not at ſolemne feaſts only.
Q. How may deſire be ſtirred in vs?
A. By due conſideration of our owne neceſſity, Mat. 9.12. Pſal. 63.1.2.3. and the ſacraments vertue and the meditation of Chriſts command.
Q. What is the third thing requiſite in a Worthy communicant?
A. Iuſtifying faith, Rom. 4.11. a man muſt bring his euidence that hath any good by the ſeale.
Q. What is faith?
A. Faith is a ſaueing grace whereby wee goe out of our ſelues, Epheſ. 2.8. Phil 3.9. and reſt vpon Chriſt alone for ſaluation.
Q. Why is faith neceſſary?

A. Faith is neceſſary to the acceptable performance of euery part of Gods worſhip, Heb. 11.6. Ioh 4.10. Ioh. 1.12. Eph. 3 17. its the ground of true deſire after the Sacrament, its the mouth and hand of the ſoule to receiue Chriſt offered in the Sacrament.
Q. How ſhall a man know whether he hath faith?

A, Firſt by the nature of faith, Rom. 10. Pſal. 116 10. 2 Iam. 17 1 Pet 22 Iſa. 28.16 ſecondly by the meanes whereby true faith is wrought, for faith is wrought by the word & ſpirit, thirdly by the fruits which are prayer, loue to the word, obedience and dependance on God,
Q. How ſhall a man get faith?
A. By hearing the word and ſeeking it at Gods hand. Rom. 10 Mar. 9.2
Q. What is the fourth thing in worthy receiuing?
A. Repentance,

A. Becauſe wee come to haue pardon of ſinne ſealed to vs here which preſuppoſeth repentance and if the conſcience be defiled with any knowne ſinne, Act. 5.3 • Tit. 1.15. Hag, 2.15 14. Num. 6.6 7. &c. ler. 4.1. Ioel. 1.12 Lom. 3.40 Iam. 4 9. 1 Cor. 11 31. Eze 36 3 Prov. 28. Pſal. 51. 1 Ier. 7.5. it defiles our ſeruices, none might come to the paſſeouer which were not legally cleane.
Q. What is repentance?
A. A turning from ſinne to God.
Q. What particulars are required therein?
A. Firſt examination to finde out ſinne. 2 Affection to morne for it and to iudge our ſelues and to hate it. 3 Confeſſion. 4 An hearty deſire of pardon. 5 Reſolution againſt ſinne.
Q. How may wee finde out ſinne?

A. By comparing our ſelues to the law of God which ſhould be the rule of our actions.
• om. 7.7.3.20. •• m. 1.23. • .
Q. How ſhall we know whether wee haue repented?
A. It workes an vniverſall change, Cor. 7.11. Cor. 6.11. it makes vs of fooliſh wiſe, of carnall ſpirituall, of prophane holy in all our conuerſations.
Q. How ſhall we get repentance?

A. We muſt ſeeke it of Chriſt whoſe office it is to giue it and in the word by which as an inſtrument it is wrought.
• ct. 5.31.2 37. Tim. 2.25

p.hi: Q. What may further helpe to breake our hearts for ſinne?

div.p:
A. The conſideration of Gods infinite wrath againſt ſinne,
• en. 3.16. 〈◊〉 . 18.19. • ſal. 7.11. •• ph 5.6.2.53. to the •• d 2.55.6.7.1.3.12. manifeſted in the puniſhment of Adam & his poſteritie, all the iudgments of this life and hell hereafter, & the puniſhment he laid on Chriſt, as alſo thought of his mercy in pardoning ſinne if wee repent.
Q. What is the fifth thing in worthy receiuing?
A. Loue to God, Cor. 11. and peace and loue to our neighbours.
Q. Why is loue neceſſary?
A. God here ſeales his loue to vs, 1 Cor. 10 17. Mat. 5.23.24. 1 Tim. 2.8. and ſeales our vnion one with another, it is a loue feaſt, beſides no ſervice is accepted which is not done in loue.
Q. What is loue?
A. A gracious affection of the heart whereby we wiſh and endeavour good to all eſpecially to the godly. Gal. 5.22. 1 Cor. 13. Gal. 6.10.
Q. How ſhall wee knowe whether wee haue loue?
A. By the fruits ſuch are ſympathy couering infirmities, forgiuing iniuries. 1 Cor. 13.4 5.6.7. Rom. 12.1 • 1 Pet. 4.8. Gal. 5.22.
Q. How ſhall we attaine this loue?
A. By praier, for it is a fruit of the ſpirit.
Q. What muſt we do if there be any breach of loue betweene vs and others?
A. Seeke reconciliation and not omit the Sacrament. Mat. 5.23.24:
Q. What if reconciliation cannot be had?
A. If it be truly ſought for on our part we are ſafe it is our owne not others malice which makes vs vnfit for the Sacrament. 1 Cor. 11.28.
Q. What if they haue prouoked vs & made no ſatisfaction?
A. Yet wee muſt forgiue and not deſire revenge, Col. 3.12.13. Chriſt muſt be our rule who forgaue vs freely.
Q. What is the laſt thing neceſſary in preparation?
A. A purpoſe to keepe that Couenant which we made in Baptiſme, and now renew in the Lords Supper.
Q, Why is this neceſſary?

A. Becauſe without this a man mocks God making ſhew of covenanting with him but thinks of nothing leſſe, and this purpoſe of new obedience is a neceſſary fruit of faith.
•• m. 2.17.
Q, How may we knowe whether wee haue this purpoſe?
A. Our conſciences are the only witneſſes in this, when wee make a covenant with a man we knowe whether wee meane to keepe it ſo may we in our couenant with God.
Q. What helps may wee haue in attaining this?

A. We muſt conſider if our purpoſes bee ſyncere Chriſt will helpe vs to keep them, accept ſyncere though weake ſervice and giue vs an ineſtimable reward, Cor. 8.12. Mat. 25.34. ſo it will be the beſt bargaine that can be made.
Q. What if we finde not this qualification?
A. If we haue it not in ſome meaſure, 1 Cor. 11. • 8. we muſt ſeeke it before wee preſume to come to the Lords Table, there be degrees in it the more preparation the more fruit.
Q. What is the danger of vnworthy receiving?
A. Very great, for inſteed of hauing benefit by Chriſts blood, 1 Cor. 11.21.29. we are guilty of it and make our ſelues liable to temporall and eternall iudgments.
Q. Is it not beſt then to omit this Sacrament?
A. No abſenting from the Sacrament is no better, Mat 22.3.7 Heb. 10.25. nor ſafer then the prophaning of it.
Q. What muſt we then doe if we finde want of preparation?
A. Lament our wants and deſire and endeauour after theſe graces and we ſhall be accepted. Mat. 5.6. 2 Cor. 8.12. 2 Chron. 30.19.
Q. If we haue once beene prepared may we be afterwards ſecure?
A. No, 1 Cor. 11.30.31. we muſt prepare a new for there are required not only the habits of theſe graces but renewed acts ſo them.
Q. What demeanor is required of vs in receiving?
A. Such reverence as becomes the Table of ſo great a God.
Q. What elſe?

A. We muſt haue our mindes ſet on work by the ſignes to meditate on the thing ſignified,
and with ioy remember the ſufferings of Chriſt and apply them.
Q. What muſt wee doe after participation?
A. We muſt giue thankes to God for vouchſafing vs to be his gueſts at his table as we giue thanks after an ordinary meale.
Q. What is to be done elſe?
A. Wee muſt remember our couenant with God and ſtriue to keepe it.
Q. What elſe?
A. Wee muſt examine and conſider whether we profit by the Sacrament or not.
Q. What if a man be worſe after it?
A. If he be ſo indeed, then hee hath eaten vnworthily and muſt be humbled.
Q. What if wee finde benefit by the Sacrament? 1 Cor. 11.31.

A. We muſt be very thankfull and greatly reioyce, Ioh. 6.33.35. for Chriſt is the bread of life: hee that once eateth of Chriſt ſpiritually ſhall be ſure to bee nouriſhed to eternall life, he may bee ſicke in his ſoule but hee ſhall neuer die.
